Thanks for bringing this up. There have been several discussions in the community around related questions 
- https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/how-to-handle-partial-tile/408/2
- https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/loop-partitioning-and-tensorization-work-on-different-ir-levels/876

I am editing this issue to an RFC so folks can do more discussions in here. So far, we didn't directly tackle the problem, mainly because in the case of common deep learning workloads, most of the things are quite regular. However, this is an important thing that should be tackled.

There are a few solutions like you mentioned, which falls into three categories

- 1) Loop partition into a stable loop and a tail: TVM already has the pass, although it may not well optimized.
- 2) Predicated load: This usually need special hardware support
- 3) Automate padding: pad the input or output to a regular size before continue.

The main drawback of loop partition and predication is that they need special hardware support. Loop partition requires the processor to have both scalar and vector unit, while predication needs hw to support predication.  So far I personally like the automatic padding solution the best, as it can happen at a high level and still works for accelerator case.

Let us keep this issue open for discussions around these directions, and hopefully, we can have a few solutions to try out.

Hey, it would be great if you can add a [unit test](https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/pull_request.html)(either in python or c++). I personally prefer c++ since the test and implementation will be in the same language and it's easier to debug in the future.

@wweic Thanks for your comment. This is a minor change that just fixing a bug. It's not easy to create a test inside nnvm as the ops containing subgraph attrs are all inside MXNet. Also, I even don't see any tests  with subgraphs, I'm not sure if this feature could be tested inside nnvm.

I agree that without first two working (efficiently) in tvm, padding seems the only way. 
That's my current workaround for this issue. 
I only call it a workaround instead of a solution. 

If the padding is really "auto" (internal in tvm), it will be nice.
But the current case seems requiring users' effort at a high-level.  
The key issue is that the padding size might be highly associated with split/tile sizes, 
which are parameters of low-level transformation. 
That seems slightly contradicting the design of decoupling high-level/low-level IR.

-L
@wincle  replied on discussion forum.

@ZhennanQin Thanks. As the contribution guide said, `Add test-cases to cover the new features or bugfix the patch introduces`. We should try our best to follow the guide so the code base maintain good test coverage(or growing!), and we will be more confident reviewing changes cause it's covered by unit test. Please don't get me wrong, bug fixes are great! I'm just trying to see if we can improve it further. 

I think for this fix, if you have the JSON representation of such graph, you can easily call `g.apply("LoadJSON")` and verify the graph is correctly parsed. I believe you must have verified the fix in some way? How difficult is it to dump the problematic op into JSON? This is just some idea, feel free to ignore it if it's too much work for you. It will also help if you can share how you verify the fix in the pull request description.
@hlu1 Thanks for the contribution, can you clarify the difference between caffe2 model ingestion vs ONNX based conversion, would onnx frontend suffice to support caffe2 model?
@wweic Please look #1923 as pointed by Siva above. They are comprehensive changes and superset of this PR. I will close this PR (#1884 ).

I understand that improving test coverage is important, and it could protect your change not being broken in future. But as I said, it's difficult to add such a test inside NNVM repo, while it's much easier to add in MXNet.

For your suggestion, I could upload the json of my graph that can trigger this bug, but it would parse correctly even before merging my fix. Because the bug is caused from Cached_op parser, which will generate incorrect Cached_op params before this fix. As Cached_op isn't a part of NNVM repo, if I want to add such a test, I guess I need to create a fake Cached_op inside NNVM to simulate its parser behavior, which is a bit over work for such a small bug fix.

I agree that manual padding is a workaround, automatic padding is more desirable in most cases. The first two approaches are great, but also have their limitations(if you are targeting ASIC which don't have scalar unit)

As for the cases of decoupling of IRs, or compute/schedule. In many cases, such de-coupling is indeed imperfect (when considering padding, layout or wino-grad algorithm), and we are taking a pragmatic approach in solving this problem and allow the high level to be aware of low-level things when they can, but also embraces a slight coupled declaration if that brings performance gains. 

While the compute/schedule decoupling is somehow blurred, the AutoTVM topi abstraction still allows effective de-coupling of generic operator(conv2d) from underlying schedules, and that works relatively well in the current use-cases.

Our end goal is to design the end to end stack to pragmatically solve the deep learning problem, in many cases we find that indeed co-design the high-level/low-level IR are necessary.
Since this is a UnionFind data structure, the procedure should guarantee that there is no self-reference(root->parent == root). So this is not really a fix. We should check the caller.

Mostly because of int8 quantization. ONNX quantization is WIP, but moving very slowly. The caffe2 int8 backend is being open sourced now (https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/pull/13065). We don't want to be blocked by the ONNX quantization work.

Conversion dry run is not a straight forward as checkpoint to protobuf conversion need https://github.com/tensorflow/models (to generate initial protobuf) and freeze_graph built from tensorflow source to embed checkpoint into it.

I may revisit into simplifying/automating this later for nightly build. For now I will leave a doc @ docs/frontend/tensorflow.md.

@merrymercy Are there cases where dilation is used in tophub logs? To convert old logs to new workload, I will add a dilation field to all old logs. Since we don't have dilation previously, if dilation is used we will have dilated kernel shape in the workload.

the reason we do this is that, we can eliminate the backward dependence for fake loops(with extent=1) when we inject sync in coproc_sync pass. Actually we improve the coproc_sync to support injecting syncs across the pipelines compared to inject just for neighbors of pipelines, and also we inject syncs based on dependence compared to only consider if they are from different pipelines. that's why we got backward dependence for loops. so these loops with extent = 1 hurt performance badly.

I understand the reason you mentioned. another solution i come up with is that add a new pass to mark all these fake loops as unrolled, and also expose a flag to users.

Anyway, I can close this and send a new one based on our discussion result.

Hi @tqchen thanks for the answer.
I've noticed some difference between python and c++ api parts, for example:
I didn't find any option to dump IR after each pass, same as gcc does with "-fdump-tree-all" for GIMPLE IR, or so on, with c++ API, as far as I understood, this feature only available for python API, could you please share your thoughts about c++ api, would it be good to add the same functionality as python has  or may be just keep all in shared library and just call needed function from every api for different languages to keep it consistently.
Thanks.

@tqchen:  I modified the code.  
1.  Proper camel case and braces - done.
2.  Moving utility functions out of main header - done with caveats:

I moved the utility functions into a details header similar to what boost does.  Moving them to a cc file would involve adding the file *and* modifying the cmake system to include 1 cc file.  This seems like a more heavyweight change especially for essentially 1 liners that someone who was auditing the gemm code would want to read; thus in a header near the gemm code makes the system, in my opinion, more discoverable.

I am trying to make the result as readable as possible and avoid modifying the build system for those short one liners.  Is there a more appropriate place to put these sort of helper functions than a separate cc file?  

Please consider that the CallGemm function itself is a private utility function for each gemm implementation that has to be described in a header file as it is a template operator-based function.

In any case, I am happy to make more changes and ready for next review step.
I think we should close this. We can, however, enforce unroll of loop with extent=1 in the loop unrolling pass

This is a good question :) 

The current principle is: if some API is stabilized and needed across languages, we bring it to C++. If something is in flux and not yet critical to the developments, we will keep it in the language bindings(e.g. python), let it plays out and wait until it stablizes.

Admittedly there are tradeoffs, having everything in c++ makes the API available to all languages, but it is also not necessarily flexible. For example, in the case of monitoring, printing things out to a log may not be as flexible as defining a customized callback and let the user do what they want to do. 

Having some of the things in python(for example, most of our test cases are) gives some speed up to the development process and allows us to write more test cases easily.

In both cases, we should document it clearly, so it would be really nice to have a tutorial to teach users on all the possible ways to do tracing
As a side note, in this particular case, the my_debug function can be registered in c++ as well, because the runtime system allows interop between languages
please also check other backends(vulkan, opencl, metal, rocm, nvptx) to add this function, you might need to lookup the specific reference of each backend

@hlu1 Before diving into details, on high level, the caffe2 converter is actually really similar to the onnx one, if bypass onnx work is your intention, can you verify if onnx/caffe2 converter can be differentiated with modular settings? 

Seems like the only difference is how you get the op sets, either by loading a onnx model or run caffe2 to get the blob list?
@cowanmeg @eqy @jroesch please review

I think given that caffe2 represents a more up to date state of pytorch/caffe2 models, it makes sense to bring in this frontend, but like @zhreshold suggested, maybe we could modularize the code so that onnx and caffe2 frontend shares most of the code, except for a few operator set conversion mechanism
Looks good to me, this is because the `tvm::Expr` classes don't have their own specialize NodeRef classes? (like I did in Relay)

@tqchen and @zhreshold, thanks for the suggestion. I think it makes sense to modularize the code whenever possible. There are several differences between the onnx and caffe2 frontends:
1. How the opset is loaded. As @zhreshold noted, caffe2 loads the model by parsing caffe2.proto and onnx loads the model by parsing onnx.proto.
2. For the operators that are similar or even identical, mostly elementwise and math ops, the OpConverter can definitely be shared
3. The nn ops are where they differ the most, because:
- Caffe2 supports both NCHW and NHWC layouts. The float32 backend mostly uses NCHW, but the int8 backend is NHWC only. ONNX supports only NCHW.
- Caffe2 uses a larger set of arguments/attributes. For example, there are three ways to represent kernel shape: 'kernel', 'kernels', or 'kernel_h' and 'kernel_w', similarly for padding, strides, and dilations. 
- In some ops, caffe2 handles tensor flattening implicitly. For example. in the FC(dense) op, the input can be a 4D or 2D tensor, which is flattened into a 2D tensor inside the op.

  Given these differences, I find it hard to differentiate the caffe2/onnx converters with modular settings. For these ops, I think we need to re-implement the classmethod `_impl` at the very least.
Yes

This is indeed a limitation of current type solver, however, a bit more delibration might be needed as we previously discussed in #1779 with @jroesch , on how to resolve recursive types. As this won't impact the type checker's usecase now and it only limits the case the inferencer will handle, I would propose we wait until we reach a concensus and get a good solution for all cases

cc @tqchen

Let me try this. :)
It is all about semantics of split, particularly for tail condition.

The current semantics of split is to split iteration space inner and outer by a factor k. (a) When there is a tail condition, put if guard in every outer and inner.

The proposed one is (b) When there is a tail condition, put if guard in the tail.

The potential low-level tvm's padding is (c) When there is a tail condition, tvm implicitly extend the original space, (and then crop it?).

Another one good like shifting, (d) When there is a tail condition, tvm shift the last iteration inside.

The high-level padding is (e) this situation wouldn't happen, since we handle properly in high-level.
(Joking)

To me, (a) seems a little bit dumb.
(b), (c), (d) is reasonable.
How to achieve them depends on the codegen.
tvm can always generate proper instruction, like predicated or scalarization. 

The semantics of vectorize is "a suggestion to vectorize a iteration axis".
It could be relaxed. In the case of current tvm, (a), it gets relaxed by if condition.
In (b), it is only relaxed in the tail.
(c) and (d), not relaxed.
It is hard to judge which one is faster without context.
tvm can introduce all tail condition as a part of split schedule.

For ASIC having no scalar unit, I think that is totally different thing.
If a user could always write a vectorization unfriendly schedule or code and ask to generate code to that ASIC, it could fail that ASIC too.
tvm still need a proper schedule for an ASIC.
Making your semantics to overfit an ASIC seems weird to me. 
If tvm takes tail condition as a part of split schedule, for ASIC, we can just use proper tail condition.
Also, using high-level padding does not contract with the refinement of split's semantics.
But binding tvm with a high-level ir and then implicitly forcing people to it by leaving a inefficient code in tvm seems also weird to me.
It should be a user's choice to use a high-level ir or not.

-L

`test_forward_reduce` and `test_forward_reduce` are failed because `TOPI_REDUCE_ATLEAST1D` is 0:
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/44df04a1ef1d0f6dd36b0863695e5ea021d9d759/topi/include/topi/reduction.h#L27-L29

so that `MakeReduceTargetShape` deduced empty shape for reduction op that reduces on all axes:
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/44df04a1ef1d0f6dd36b0863695e5ea021d9d759/topi/include/topi/reduction.h#L107-L109

I think we should always set `TOPI_REDUCE_ATLEAST1D` to 1? @tqchen

Have seen similar issue with below sub graph where entire graph can be pruned to a param.

```
Graph(%InceptionV4/Logits/PreLogitsFlatten/flatten/Shape, %InceptionV4/Logits/PreLogitsFlatten/flatten/Reshape/shape/1) {
  %1 = strided_slice(%InceptionV4/Logits/PreLogitsFlatten/flatten/Shape, stride='[1]', begin='[0]', end='[1]')
  %2 = reshape(%1, shape='(1,)')
  %3 = expand_dims(%2, num_newaxis='1', axis='0')
  %5 = expand_dims(%InceptionV4/Logits/PreLogitsFlatten/flatten/Reshape/shape/1, num_newaxis='1', axis='0')
  %6 = concatenate(%3, %5, axis='0')
  ret %6
}

```

The forward of WarpCTC is just softmax, So Just  change to softmax.

I agree (b) (c) are reasonable choices. Actually, by automatic padding, I do mean (c). Shifting the loop range have quite a lot of problems, especially in reduction, which makes it undesirable. 

Making things ASIC compatible is an explicit choice we make, and that may not be a bad one, given the extensive use of tensorization even in modern GPUs and future CPUs. 

I agree that it is important to make low-level IR better(which in turn makes everything better). It is also important to acknowledge the limitations of the low-level approach and keep co-design in mind, that is why tvm contains both high-level and low-level IR and co-design them together.

Contributions are welcomed :)

related https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/program-crash-in-llvm-7-0/930
It seems some fixes to codegen is needed for llvm 7.0

Thanks for bringing this up. Can you elaborate a bit on what is going on here? The second issue sounds like an overly conservative detection. 

Most normal user will use select as if_then_else and they are error-prone in the context of padding(depending on whether the device support OOB read, we want to be safe on it). So this rewriting is to support this semantics here. You can also think this as a rewriting if_then_else back to select.

TOPI TOPI_REDUCE_ATLEAST1D is set to 0 because it is compatible with numpy convention and we decide to force new code(relay(nnvmv2)) toward that direction, we will need to fix the other part of the code(likely the testcases)

Yes, the second issue is about overly conservative detection.
The detector classified non-OOB to OOB. It might because  it failed to simplifying one branch of stmt. (The root reason I am not sure.)

In the current situation with Pad op test case, tvm rewrote select to if_then_else under vectorization, and failed llvm.
Fundamentally, it is not about OOB access. 
IMO, OOB shouldn't be involved in the programming model. 

It is more about semantics of select. 
IMO, the good semantics of select for general modern architectures will be something like this.

Both true and false stmt will executed before the condition stmt in arbitrary order. 
If there are exceptions or side-effect on those stmts, use as your risk.
(We could further say one stmt could be eliminated as one optimization. but that didn't impact the semantics)
This is similar to CUDA's definition for branch.
With this definition, users guard their safety for using select. 

Then, if a user has its own lower pass with particular hw support, and they can use unsafe select.
Then they can use unsafe one. 

Then, we can put that currently overly conservative UnsafeDetector to debug mode.
When you want to refine it, you refine later. :)
Thanks for bringing this up, please open a new thread at https://discuss.tvm.ai/

I agree that this might be a better choice for performance. However, as select has also been extensively used for OOB read(padding), 

The main problem is most high-level languages don't have select at all and it is usually a low-level construct. But people tend to use select in the place which they actually want if_then_else. Given this situation, we take a compromise by using unsafe-select rewriter to rewrite the un-safe ones. 

We will likely need to keep this behavior for this compatibility reason. In the most comonly usecases(padding) or constant folding, the current behavior can generate good code. We can, however, introduce a new intrinsic e.g. branch which the unsafe rewriter ignores if necessary

I like this design.
Autotvm uses arguments as workload directly, this can automate a lot of things.

Previously for altered operator, we will convert the altered workload to the original workload and query the log. This results in strange logic in `_conv_arg_to_workload` and contradicts the goal of automating config dispatching.
After this PR, we can make sure **all records in ApplyHistoryBest context exactly match the arguments in function calls**, so we can delete all things like `_conv_arg_to_workload`, `_conv2d_NCHWc_arg_to_workload`
Then we can use [`autotvm.register_topi_compute`](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/cbf4fdbbbf4993849342906722e776d332f2e97d/python/tvm/autotvm/task/topi_integration.py#L25), `autotvm.register_topi_schedule`. These two decorators will help you to do all things related to workload/config dispatching. I have used these two decorators for depthwise_conv2d since depthwise_conv2d doesn' need alter_op_layout. 

Using the update mechanism in this PR, we can make the code simpler. I can follow with updates for other backends (cuda, arm cpu)

After thinking a bit more about this, I think I agree with you on pin down the semantics of Select. This, however, would involve an upgrade of most code since many users assumed the semantics of if_then_else when using select. So it is more of matter of a safe upgrade and when to do so, one possible way to is:

- introduce tvm.if_then_else, which serves as original select
- migrate the code to use if_then_else
- Keep the current UnsafeSelectDetector and throw an error to the user, to tell them to use if_then_else instead, this will at least give users a head up about this case
- allow to optionally turn the unsafe detector off

Thanks, love you.
Let me confirm 1) Select will be kept. 
and we will have 2) capability of disabling RewriteUnsafeSelect.
This will work.

BTW, I need to correct one thing.
Pad I mentioned is the Pad op, topi's or defined in onnx. 
It doesn't rely on OOB read.
If i remember correctly in topi, you shift OOB read to edge read, so OOB won't happen.

@PariksheetPinjari909 I have already tried this.
But im facing a strange issue with concatenate for some specific values in graph_runtime create.
I reported an issue here
https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/graphruntimecreate-is-in-deadloop/1032
Waiting for replys.
[This](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/42dc24a310170577f929f648f477ca2567c8bc9a/nnvm/python/nnvm/frontend/darknet.py#L303) can be replaced with the below code and all the region op in topi/nnvm can be removed.
```
def _darknet_region(inputs, attrs):
    """Process the region operation."""
    num = attrs.get('n', 1)
    classes = attrs.get('classes', 1)
    coords = attrs.get('coords', 0)
    background = attrs.get('background', 0)
    softmax = attrs.get('softmax', True)
    input_shape = attrs.get('shape')

    split_size = classes + coords + 1;
    intermediate_shape = (input_shape[0], num, split_size, input_shape[2], input_shape[3])
    data_block = _sym.reshape(inputs[0], shape=intermediate_shape)
    split_res = _sym.split(data_block, indices_or_sections=split_size, axis=2)
    splits = []
    for i in split_res:
        splits.append(i)
    splits[0] = _sym.sigmoid(splits[0])
    splits[1] = _sym.sigmoid(splits[1])
    if not background:
        splits[coords] = _sym.sigmoid(splits[coords])
    if softmax:
        offset = coords + int(not background)
        softmax_input = _sym.concatenate(*splits[offset:], axis=2)
        softmax_output = _sym.softmax(softmax_input, axis=2)
        data_block_1 = splits[:offset]
        splits = data_block_1 + [softmax_output]
    concat_out = _sym.concatenate(*splits, axis=2)
    return _sym.reshape(concat_out, shape=input_shape), None
```
